elements.content: A series of Ag(I) complexes with zero-, one- and two-dimensional structures have been successfully prepared by the reactions of 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline, L, with corresponding Ag(I) salts in various solvents, which were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectra and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complexes of the type [Ag(L)2](X) (X = ClO4, 1; X = PF6, 2; and X = SbF6, 3) are monomeric, while the complexes {[Ag(L)(L′)][X]}∞ (X = BF4, L′ = H2O, 4; X = BF4, L′ = CH3CN, 5; and X = ClO4, L′ = CH3CN, 6), [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)·0.5CH3OH·H2O]∞, 7·0.5CH3OH·H2O, and {[Ag(L)][SbF6]·0.5CH2Cl2}∞, 8·0.5CH2Cl2, show 1-D polymeric infinite chains. The ClO4 − anions in complex 6 interact with the rings in a tridentate bonding mode forming the rare [ClO4-π] n zigzag chain. The molecules of the complex Ag2(L)(NO3)2(DMF)2, 9, are dinuclear, while complexes of the type [Ag2(L)(NO3)2(L′)2]∞ (L′ = H2O, 10, and L′ = CH3CN, 11) show 1-D ladderlike chain structures, and the [Ag2(L)]2+ units are interlinked by H2O molecules and/or NO3 − anions. The complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2]∞, 12, and [Ag(L)(p-TsO)]∞ (p-TsO = p-toluenesulfonate), 13, show 2-D distorted hexagonal net and 2-D pleated rectangular grids, respectively. For complexes 1−8 with noncoordinating anions, those with coordinated or packed solvent molecules show the polymeric structures, whereas those without solvent molecule are mononuclear. For complexes 9−13, the nitrate and p-toluenesulfonate ions are found to be coordinating and the bonding modes of nitrate anions are dependent on the nature of the solvents. All the complexes exhibit emissions which may be tentatively assigned as intraligand (IL) π → π* transitions.

elements.content: The self-assembly of supramolecular structures using metal coordination has attracted a great deal of attention over the past decade, due to the range of potential applications in electrical, magnetic, and optical devices and porous zeolite mimics. Many topologically promising architectures have been constructed for the Ag(I) ion with bidentate building blocks containing nitrogen donor. The various types of polymeric structure include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures. Despite some recent progress, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of molecules remains elusive, and much more work is required to understand the inter- and intramolecular forces that determine the patterns of molecular structure and crystal packing in the solid state.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The self-assembly of supramolecular structures using metal coordination has attracted a great deal of attention over the past decade, due to the range of potential applications in electrical, magnetic, and optical devices and porous zeolite mimics. Many topologically promising architectures have been constructed for the Ag(I) ion with bidentate building blocks containing nitrogen donor. The various types of polymeric structure include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures. Despite some recent progress, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of molecules remains elusive, and much more work is required to understand the inter- and intramolecular forces that determine the patterns of molecular structure and crystal packing in the solid state.

elements.content: In addition to the nature of the metal atoms and the ligands, counterion-based interaction is one of the common factors that can be modulated to determine the structure. The size of the anion has been shown to exert a significant effect on the structural type. In the reactions of 3,6-bis(2-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine (bptz) with solvated first-row transition metals, it was shown that the relatively small anions, ClO4 − and BF4 −, lead to the formation of molecular squares, whereas the larger anion SbF6 − favors the molecular pentagon. In the reactions of 3,6-dicyano-9-phenylcarbazole (dcphcz) with the Ag(I) metal salts, it was found that the bulkier CF3SO3 − and CF3CO2 − anions possess stronger coordination ability than BF4 − and ClO4 − anions and serve as linkages to bridge the 1-D chains to 2-D metal-organic frameworks with Ag−O contacts. The effect of the noncoordinating anion on the structural type has been the subject of several studies and the bidentate ligand 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline, L, has been used to construct several monovalent complexes having mononuclear and 1-D structures. For noncoordinating anions, the small ones lead to a polymeric cation complex and the larger ones exert a nonproliferating effect in the countercation, and the nature of the solvent seems to have little effect on these general observations.

elements.content: Herein we report our results on the reactions of Ag(I) metal salts with L in various solvents. We have found that metal-to-ligand molar ratio and nature of the solvents involved in the reactions play important roles in determining the structural type of the Ag(I)−L complexes containing coordinating or noncoordinating anion. For complexes with noncoordinating anions, those with coordinated or packed solvent molecules show polymeric structures, whereas those without solvent molecule are mononuclear. The syntheses, structures and luminescent properties of the monomeric complexes [Ag(L)2](X) (X = ClO4, 1; X = PF6, 2; and X = SbF6, 3), the 1-D polymeric chain complexes {[Ag(L)(L′)][X]}∞ (X = BF4, L′ = H2O, 4; X = BF4, L′ = CH3CN, 5; and X = ClO4, L′ = CH3CN, 6), [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)·0.5CH3OH·H2O]∞, 7·0.5CH3OH·H2O, and {[Ag(L)][SbF6]·0.5CH2Cl2}∞, 8·0.5CH2Cl2, the dinuclear complex Ag2(L)(NO3)2(DMF)2, 9, the 1-D ladder like chain complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2(L′)2]∞ (L′ = H2O, 10, and L′ = CH3CN, 11) and the 2-D net complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2]∞, 12, and [Ag(L)(p-TsO)]∞, 13, form the subject of this report.

elements.content: All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. Diethyl ether and THF were purified by distillation from sodium/benzophenone, CH3CN from CaH2, CH2Cl2 from P2O5, methanol from Mg/I2. IR spectra (KBr disk) were collected on a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or a HERAEUS VaruoEL analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. Diethyl ether and THF were purified by distillation from sodium/benzophenone, CH3CN from CaH2, CH2Cl2 from P2O5, methanol from Mg/I2. IR spectra (KBr disk) were collected on a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer or a HERAEUS VaruoEL analyzer.

elements.content: The reagents AgPF6, AgNO3, AgClO4, AgSbF6, and AgBF4 were purchased from Strem Chemical Co. Acetone, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1,4-dioxane AgCF3SO3 and Ag(p-TsO) (p-TsO = p-toluenesulfonate) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. All the reagents were used as received. The ligand 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline, L, was prepared according to a previously reported procedure. CAUTION: Perchlorate salts are dangerous (especially if they are dry) and should be handled with care!
elements.clean_text:
Materials

The reagents AgPF6, AgNO3, AgClO4, AgSbF6, and AgBF4 were purchased from Strem Chemical Co. Acetone, N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1,4-dioxane AgCF3SO3 and Ag(p-TsO) (p-TsO = p-toluenesulfonate) were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. All the reagents were used as received. The ligand 2,3-diphenylquinoxaline, L, was prepared according to a previously reported procedure.  CAUTION: Perchlorate salts are dangerous (especially if they are dry) and should be handled with care!

elements.content: L (0.57 g, 2.0 mmol) was placed in a flask containing 15 mL of MeOH, and AgClO4 (0.21 g, 1.0 mmol) was added. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 24 h to afford a yellow solution with some white solid. The solution was filtered and then diethyl ether added to introduce precipitate, which was filtered and washed with diethyl ether (2 × 10 mL) and then dried under vacuum to give a white product. Colorless crystals were obtained by slow diffusion of diethyl ether into a methanol solution of the compound for several weeks. Yield: 0.65 g (85% based on Ag). Anal. Calcd for C40H28AgClN4O4 (MW = 771.98): C, 62.63; H, 3.66; N, 7.26. Found: C, 62.75; H, 3.21; N, 7.56%. IR (cm−1): 3054(br), 1562(w), 1479(m), 1220(s), 1110(w), 1058(w), 811(m).

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1−13. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1−3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, respectively. The first weight loss of 37.0, 35.0 and 30.6% occurred in the temperature range 213−266 °C for 1, 218−270 °C for 2 and 214−271 °C for 3, respectively, presumably due to the removal one of the L ligands per formula unit (calcd 36.6, 34.6 and 31.1%). Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 266−370 °C for 1, 270−314 °C for 2 and 271−382 °C for 3, corresponding to the removal of the second L ligands and decomposition of the structures.

Thermal Gravimetric Analyses

Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1-13. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1-3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, respectively. The first weight loss of 37.0, 35.0 and 30.6% occurred in the temperature range 213-266 °C for 1, 218-270 °C for 2 and 214-271 °C for 3, respectively, presumably due to the removal one of the L ligands per formula unit (calcd 36.6, 34.6 and 31.1%). Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 266-370 °C for 1, 270-314 °C for 2 and 271-382 °C for 3, corresponding to the removal of the second L ligands and decomposition of the structures.

elements.content: The TGA curve shows that 4 is stable up to 95 °C. A total weight loss of 7.2% occurred in the temperature range 95−150 °C, mainly corresponding to the removal of the cocrystallized and the bonded H2O molecules per formula unit (calcd 7.0%). Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 240−350 °C, consistent with the removal of L ligands and decomposition of the chain structures. TGA curves for 5 and 6 show the loss of the bonded MeCN groups in the range 128−164 °C for 5 and 132−162 °C for 6 (calcd 8.0%, obs 7.7% for 5 and calcd 7.7%, obs 7.4% for 6), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the chains in 260−355 °C for 5 and 250−360 °C for 6, respectively. The TGA curves show that the 1-D chains 7 and 8 are stable up to 210 and 213 °C, respectively. The weight losses occurred in the temperature range 210−434 °C for 7 and 213−440 °C for 8 are due to the removal the L ligands and decomposition of the chain structures.

elements.content: The TGA curve for 9 shows the loss of the bonded DMF groups in the range 120−160 °C (calcd 19.0%, obs 18.7%), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the structures above 190−270 °C, while those for 10 and 11 show the loss of the bonded H2O or MeCN groups in the range 95−115 °C for 10 and 85−110 °C for 11 (calcd 5.4%, obs 5.7% for 10 and calcd 12.5%, obs 12.4% for 11), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the chains above 205−270 °C for 10 and 210−265 °C for 11, respectively. The TGA curves show that the 2-D networks 12 and 13 are stable up to 195 and 200 °C, respectively. The first weight loss of 44.9 and 49.8% occurred in the temperature range 195−274 °C for 12 and 200−344 °C for 13, presumably due to the removal the L ligands per formula unit (calcd 45.4 and 50.3%), respectively. Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 274−385 °C for 12 and 344−493 °C for 13, corresponding to the removal of the anions and decomposition of the structures.

elements.content: The diffraction data for complexes 1, 2, 4−7 and 9−12 were collected on a Bruker AXS P4 diffractometer at 22 °C while those of 3, 8, and 13 were collected on a Bruker Kappa APEX II diffractometer at 22 °C, which was equipped with a graphite-monochromated (Mo Kα = 0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was carried by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. An empirical absorption correction based on a series of Ψ-scans was applied to the data for complexes 1, 2, 4−7 and 9−12, while the empirical absorption correction based on “multi-scan” was applied to the data for complexes 3, 8 and 13. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the silver atom, were located by direct methods. The positions of remaining atoms were located from difference Fourier maps calculated after least-squares refinements. For the complexes 1−13, all the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD program in SHELXTL 5.10. For complexes 1 and 6 the O atoms of ClO4 − anion (except O4 of 1) were found disordered over two positions (occupancy of 0.29 and 0.71 for 1; 0.50 and 0.50 for 6). The BF4 − anion of complex 4 was separated into two disordered molecules with fixed ideal geometry (occupancy of 0.33 and 0.67). The major orientation was refined anisotropically, and the minor one was refined isotropically. The O2 atom in 4 has been modeled into several disordered positions with suitable site occupancy. A water molecule and a half CH3OH molecule in each asymmetric unit were found for 7. The oxygen and carbon atoms of CH3OH molecule were disordered with equal occupancy, and the C−O distance was fixed at 1.530 Å. Large electron residues close to the heavy atoms for 7, 8 and 10 were observed, probably due to poor empirical absorption corrections. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .

Data reduction was carried by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures. The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. An empirical absorption correction based on a series of Ψ-scans was applied to the data for complexes 1, 2, 4-7 and 9-12, while the empirical absorption correction based on "multi-scan" was applied to the data for complexes 3, 8 and 13. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the silver atom, were located by direct methods. The positions of remaining atoms were located from difference Fourier maps calculated after least-squares refinements. For the complexes 1-13, all the hydrogen atoms were added by using the HADD program in SHELXTL 5.10. For complexes 1 and 6 the O atoms of ClO4 - anion (except O4 of 1) were found disordered over two positions (occupancy of 0.29 and 0.71 for 1; 0.50 and 0.50 for 6). The BF4 - anion of complex 4 was separated into two disordered molecules with fixed ideal geometry (occupancy of 0.33 and 0.67). The major orientation was refined anisotropically, and the minor one was refined isotropically. The O2 atom in 4 has been modeled into several disordered positions with suitable site occupancy. A water molecule and a half CH3OH molecule in each asymmetric unit were found for 7. The oxygen and carbon atoms of CH3OH molecule were disordered with equal occupancy, and the C-O distance was fixed at 1.530 Å. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .

The reactions of L with Ag(I) salt (L: Ag = 2: 1) in MeOH afforded the mononuclear complexes of the type [Ag(L)2](X) (X = ClO4, 1; X = PF6, 2 and X = SbF6, 3), while the 1-D polymeric complexes of the type {[Ag(L)(L′)][X]}∞ (X = BF4, L′ = H2O, 4; X = BF4, L′ = CH3CN, 5; and X = ClO4, L′ = CH3CN, 6), [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)·0.5CH3OH·H2O]∞, 7·0.5CH3OH·H2O, and {[Ag(L)][SbF6]·0.5·CH2Cl2}∞, 8·0.5·CH2Cl2, were prepared by reactions of L with the corresponding Ag(I) salt (Ag: L = 1:1) in CH3OH/H2O, CH3CN, CH3OH and CH2Cl2, respectively. The dinuclear complex Ag2(L)(NO3)2(DMF)2, 9, the 1-D ladderlike chain complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2(L′)2]∞ (L′ = H2O, 10, and L′ = CH3CN, 11) and the 2-D polymeric complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2]∞, 12, were prepared by the reactions of L with AgNO3 (Ag:L = 2:1) in DMF, CH3OH/H2O, CH3CN and THF, respectively. Several different M to L ratios (1:1, 1:2 and 1:3) have been tested for complexes 9−12, which afforded the same complexes with different yields, indicating that the stoichiometry of 9−12 is independent of the metal-to-ligand ratio. The reaction of L with Ag(p-TsO) (L:Ag = 1:1) in CH2Cl2 gave the 2-D pleated sheet complex [Ag(L)(p-TsO)]∞, 13. The reaction pathways of complexes 1−13 are shown in Scheme .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The reactions of L with Ag(I) salt (L: Ag = 2: 1) in MeOH afforded the mononuclear complexes of the type [Ag(L)2](X) (X = ClO4, 1; X = PF6, 2 and X = SbF6, 3), while the 1-D polymeric complexes of the type {[Ag(L)(L')][X]}∞ (X = BF4, L' = H2O, 4; X = BF4, L' = CH3CN, 5; and X = ClO4, L' = CH3CN, 6), [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)⋅0.5CH3OH⋅H2O]∞, 7⋅0.5CH3OH⋅H2O, and {[Ag(L)][SbF6]⋅0.5⋅CH2Cl2}∞, 8⋅0.5⋅CH2Cl2, were prepared by reactions of L with the corresponding Ag(I) salt (Ag: L = 1:1) in CH3OH/H2O, CH3CN, CH3OH and CH2Cl2, respectively. The dinuclear complex Ag2(L)(NO3)2(DMF)2, 9, the 1-D ladderlike chain complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2(L')2]∞ (L' = H2O, 10, and L' = CH3CN, 11) and the 2-D polymeric complexes [Ag2(L)(NO3)2]∞, 12, were prepared by the reactions of L with AgNO3 (Ag:L = 2:1) in DMF, CH3OH/H2O, CH3CN and THF, respectively. Several different M to L ratios (1:1, 1:2 and 1:3) have been tested for complexes 9-12, which afforded the same complexes with different yields, indicating that the stoichiometry of 9-12 is independent of the metal-to-ligand ratio. The reaction of L with Ag(p-TsO) (L:Ag = 1:1) in CH2Cl2 gave the 2-D pleated sheet complex [Ag(L)(p-TsO)]∞, 13. The reaction pathways of complexes 1-13 are shown in Scheme .

elements.content: Figure depicts a representative molecular structure for complexes 1−3, showing the arrangements about the Ag(I) metal centers, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Complexes 1−3 are mononuclear, and each Ag(I) ion bridges two L ligands. The metal−ligand bonding is characterized by the Ag−N bond lengths in the range from 2.168(4) to 2.206(2) Å with the N−Ag−N bond angles in the range from 164.01(9) to 172.32(6)°. The typical range for Ag(I)−N bond distances is 2.11−2.63 Å. The ClO4 −, PF6 − and SbF6 − anions in complexes 1−3 interact with the Ag(I) ions through Ag···O and Ag···F interactions [Ag···O = 2.790(5) and 2.894(5) Å for 1; Ag···F = 2.974(6) Å for 2; Ag···F = 2.966(2) Å for 3]. The Ag···O and Ag···F distances are shorter than their corresponding van der Waals contacts, which are 3.24 and 3.19 Å, respectively (van der Waals radius for Ag is 1.72 Å, for O is 1.52 Å and for F is 1.47 Å).

Structures of 1-3

Figure  depicts a representative molecular structure for complexes 1-3, showing the arrangements about the Ag(I) metal centers, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . Complexes 1-3 are mononuclear, and each Ag(I) ion bridges two L ligands. The metal-ligand bonding is characterized by the Ag-N bond lengths in the range from 2.168(4) to 2.206(2) Å with the N-Ag-N bond angles in the range from 164.01(9) to 172.32(6)°. The typical range for Ag(I)-N bond distances is 2.11-2.63 Å. The ClO4 -, PF6 - and SbF6 - anions in complexes 1-3 interact with the Ag(I) ions through Ag⋅⋅⋅O and Ag⋅⋅⋅F interactions [Ag⋅⋅⋅O = 2.790(5) and 2.894(5) Å for 1; Ag⋅⋅⋅F = 2.974(6) Å for 2; Ag⋅⋅⋅F = 2.966(2) Å for 3]. The Ag⋅⋅⋅O and Ag⋅⋅⋅F distances are shorter than their corresponding van der Waals contacts, which are 3.24 and 3.19 Å, respectively (van der Waals radius for Ag is 1.72 Å, for O is 1.52 Å and for F is 1.47 Å).

Figure (a)−(d) depicts the molecular structures for complexes 4−8 showing the arrangements about the Ag(I) metal centers, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Tables and . For complexes 4−7, the consecutive L ligands lying along the chains are related by the 21 screw axis and thus show a helical nature, Figure and Figure S1 in the , while complex 8 shows a zigzag chain. Each of the Ag(I) metal atoms in complexes 4−6 adopts the distorted trigonal planar geometry, and the sum of the angles about the Ag(I) atom is 360.0(5)° for 4, 358.1(4)° for 5 and 357.9(4) ° for 6, respectively. The Ag(I) and the three coordinated atoms are almost coplanar, and the mean deviation from plane is 0.0021, 0.0645, and 0.0679 Å in complexes 4−6. The Ag−N distances to the L ligands in 4− 6 are in the range from 2.192(3) to 2.262(3) Å, while the Ag−O distance to the water molecule in 4 is 2.454(6) Å and the Ag−N distances to the CH3CN molecules are 2.341(5) Å in 5 and 2.342(4) Å in 6, respectively. The typical range of Ag(I)−O bond distances is 2.3−2.6 Å. The Ag(I) ion of complex 7 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms [Ag−N = 2.193(9) and 2.275(12) Å] from two different L ligands and one oxygen atom [Ag−O = 2.554(12) Å] from the monodentate CF3SO3 − anion to form a distorted T-shaped geometry, with the angles about the Ag(I) atom of 97.8(4), 104.7(4) and 157.2(4)°, respectively. The bonded atoms and Ag(I) ion are almost coplanar with the mean deviation from the plane of 0.0376 Å. The two independent Ag(I) centers in complex 8, Ag(1) and Ag(2), are coordinated by two nitrogen atoms [Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.201(3) Å and Ag(2)−N(2) = 2.183(3) Å] from two different L ligands, and the Ag(1) atom adopts a slightly bent geometry with the N−Ag(1)−N angle of 175.67(19)°, while the geometry about Ag(2) is linear [N−Ag(2)−N = 180.0(2)°].

All the silver metal centers in 10 and 11 adopt slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry. There are three independent Ag(I) centers in complex 10. The Ag(1) atom is bonded to one terminal water molecule [Ag(1)−O(10) = 2.298(7) Å], one bridging water molecule [Ag(1)−O(11) = 2.570(6) Å], one oxygen atom of the μ2,η1,η1-NO3 − anion [Ag(1)−O(1) = 2.587(6) Å] and one nitrogen atom of the L ligand [Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.337(6) Å]. The Ag(2) atom is bonded to one bridging water molecule [Ag(2)−O(11A) = 2.515(6) Å], one oxygen atom of the μ2,η1,η1-NO3 − anion [Ag(2)−O(4) = 2.505(7) Å], one oxygen atom of the unidentate NO3 − anion [Ag(2)−O(7) = 2.467(7) Å] and one nitrogen atom of the L ligand [Ag(2)−N(2) = 2.376(6)Å], while the Ag(3) atom is bonded to two oxygen atoms from two different μ2,η1,η1-NO3 − anions [Ag(3)−O(3) = 2.454(6) Å, Ag(3)−O(5B) = 2.518(7) Å], one terminal water molecule [Ag(3)−O(12) = 2.368(6) Å] and one nitrogen atom of the L ligand [Ag(3)−N(3) = 2.327(6) Å]. Each Ag(I) ion in 11 is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from L ligand [Ag−N(1) = 2.402(3) Å] and MeCN molecule [Ag−N(2) = 2.256(4) Å] and two oxygen atoms from two different μ2,η1-NO3 − anions [Ag−O(1) = 2.449(4) Å and Ag−O(1A) = 2.533(3) Å]. Complexes 10 and 11 form the 1-D ladder like chains, Figures (a) and (b). The 14-membered {Ag4N4O2C4} and 18-membered {Ag4N6O4C4} metallocycles in complex 10 have the sizes of 7.4 × 4.7 and 7.4 × 5.1 Å2, respectively, while that of the 14-membered {Ag4N4O2C4} metallocycle in complex 11 is 7.6 × 4.6 Å2.

elements.content: There are two independent Ag(I) atoms in complex 12. The Ag(1) ion is coordinated by one nitrogen atom [Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.288(6) Å] of the L ligand and two oxygen atoms [Ag(1)−O(1) = 2.472(6) Å and Ag(1)−O(6A) = 2.504(7) Å] from two different μ2,η1,η1-NO3 − anions to adopt a highly distorted T-shaped geometry [N(1)−Ag(1)−O(6A) = 102.0(2)°, O(1)−Ag(1)−O(6A) = 91.7(2)° and O(1)−Ag(1)−N(1) = 146.1(2)°], while the Ag(2) atom is bonded to two oxygen atoms from two different μ2,η1-NO3 − anions [Ag(2)−O(1B) = 2.254(6) Å and Ag(2)−O(4) = 2.589(7) Å] and one nitrogen atom of the L ligand [Ag(2)−N(2) = 2.290(6) Å] to complete a distorted trigonal planar geometry [N(2)−Ag(2)−O(4) + O(1B)−Ag(2)−O(4) + O(1B)−Ag(2)−N(2) = 357.0°]. Complex 12 forms a 2-D distorted hexagonal net as shown in Figure (c), which is composed of two connected orthogonal chains involving −[Ag−L−Ag−(μ2,η1-NO3)]− and −[Ag−(μ2,η1,η1-NO3)−Ag−(μ2,η1-NO3)]−. The 22-membered {Ag6N6O6C4} metallocycle has the size of 13.9 × 7.1 Å2, and a schematic drawing of the 2-D (6, 3) structure is shown in Figure (d).

elements.content: The nitrate anions in complexes 9−12 show several bonding modes, including the unidentate coordination mode (complex 11), the μ2,η1-NO3 − coordination mode (complexes 10 and 12), the bidentate coordination mode (complex 9) and the μ2,η1,η1-NO3 − coordination mode (complexes 10 and 12) The formation of different bonding modes for NO3 − anions is presumably due to the different coordination abilities of the coordinating solvents, resulting in different structural types for complexes 9−12.

elements.content: Figure (a) depicts the molecular structure for complex 13 showing the arrangements about the Ag(I) metal centers, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The Ag(I) atom, which is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms [Ag−N = 2.3577(12), 2.3627(13) Å] from two different L ligands and two oxygen atoms [Ag−O = 2.4889(12), 2.5456(14) Å] from two different p-TsO− anions, forms a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The structure of complex 13 is characterized as a 2-D polymeric rectangular grids which is composed of −[Ag−L]− and −[Ag−(μ2,η1,η1-p-TsO)]− orthogonal chains, Figure (b). The 18-membered metallocycle {Ag4N4O4C4S2} has a size of 6.9 × 7.5 Å2. Figure (c) shows a schematic drawing of the 2-D (4, 4) topology.

Structure of 13

Figure (a) depicts the molecular structure for complex 13 showing the arrangements about the Ag(I) metal centers, and selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The Ag(I) atom, which is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms [Ag-N = 2.3577(12), 2.3627(13) Å] from two different L ligands and two oxygen atoms [Ag-O = 2.4889(12), 2.5456(14) Å] from two different p-TsO- anions, forms a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The structure of complex 13 is characterized as a 2-D polymeric rectangular grids which is composed of -[Ag-L]- and -[Ag-(μ2,η1,η1-p-TsO)]- orthogonal chains, Figure (b). The 18-membered metallocycle {Ag4N4O4C4S2} has a size of 6.9 × 7.5 Å2. Figure (c) shows a schematic drawing of the 2-D (4, 4) topology.

Intramolecular and intermolecular C−H···Ag short contacts between the Ag center and hydrogen atoms of the quinoxalinyl groups in complexes 1−13, as well as the C−H···π short contacts between phenyl ring and the hydrogen atom of the neighboring quinoxalinyl groups, are observed in complexes 1− 8. Pertinent distances and angles are listed in Tables S1 and S2 in the . The H···Ag distances [2.71(1)−2.92(1) Å] are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of silver and hydrogen atoms which is 2.92 Å, while the H···π distances [2.71(1)−3.04(1) Å] are shorter than the van der Waals distance of 3.05 Å on the basis of Pauling’s value for the half-thickness of a phenyl ring (1.85 Å) and the van der Waals radius of H (1.20 Å). Recent calculation for the complex {[AgL1](ClO4)}2 (L1 = 9-[3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazol-1-yl]acridine has shown strong support for the existence of C−H···Ag close interaction.

C-H⋅⋅⋅Ag, C-H⋅⋅⋅π, Anion⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π Weak Interactions

Intramolecular and intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅Ag short contacts between the Ag center and hydrogen atoms of the quinoxalinyl groups in complexes 1-13, as well as the C-H⋅⋅⋅π short contacts between phenyl ring and the hydrogen atom of the neighboring quinoxalinyl groups, are observed in complexes 1- 8. Pertinent distances and angles are listed in Tables S1 and S2 in the . The H⋅⋅⋅Ag distances [2.71(1)-2.92(1) Å] are shorter than the sum of the van der Waals radii of silver and hydrogen atoms which is 2.92 Å, while the H⋅⋅⋅π distances [2.71(1)-3.04(1) Å] are shorter than the van der Waals distance of 3.05 Å on the basis of Pauling's value for the half-thickness of a phenyl ring (1.85 Å) and the van der Waals radius of H (1.20 Å). Recent calculation for the complex {[AgL1](ClO4)}2 (L1 = 9-[3-(2-pyridyl)pyrazol-1-yl]acridine has shown strong support for the existence of C-H⋅⋅⋅Ag close interaction.

elements.content: Interesting anion−π interactions between the BF4 −, ClO4 −, CF3SO3 − or SbF6 − anion and the quinoxalinyl groups of the L ligands are found in complexes 4−8, Figure S1 in the , and Table S3 in the lists some pertinent distances. Noticeably, while two F atoms of BF4 − anions in complexes 4 and 5 interact with the quinoxalinyl groups in bidentate chelating mode, Figure S1(a),(b) in the , the ClO4 − anions in complex 6 interact with the quinoxalinyl group in a tridentate bridging mode, forming the rare [ClO4-π] n zigzag chains, Figure . The CF3SO3 − anions in 7 interact with the quinoxalinyl group through the F atoms [F···π = 3.306 (14) Å, van der Waals radius of F is 1.47 and F···π van der Waals contact is 3.32 Å], Figure S1(c) in the . In 8, the Ag(1) atom coordinates weakly to one chelating CH2Cl2 solvent molecule [Ag···Cl = 3.219(4) Å, van der Waals radius of Cl is 1.75 and Ag···Cl van der Waals contact is 3.47 Å], while the two trans SbF 6 − anions are located in the proximity of Ag(2) (Ag···F = 2.974 (6) Å), resulting in the C−H···F hydrogen bonds [H···F = 2.655(12) Å, C−H···F = 135.21(38)°] and anion···π interactions between the SbF 6 − anions and the quinoxaline groups [F···π = 3.171(9) Å], Figure S1(d) in the . In addition to the C−H···Ag and C−H···π interactions, the molecules of 9 and 12 show intermolecular π−π stacking interactions [3.546(2)−3.709(1) Å] between phenyl rings and quinoxaline groups, while those of 10, 11, and 13 show intramolecular π−π stacking interactions [3.578(1)−3.886(1) Å] between phenyl rings, Table S3 in the . The typical cutoff distance for π−π stacking interactions is 3.9 Å.

elements.content: The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1−3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, and the first weight loss which is due to the removal one of the L ligands occurred in the similar temperature ranges of 213−266 °C for 1, 218−270 °C for 2 and 214−271 °C for 3, respectively, indicating that the anions ClO4 −, PF6 − and SbF6 − play similar structural role in complexes 1−3. For complexes 4−6 which show 1-D polymeric infinite chains, the cocrystallized and the bonded H2O molecules of 4 were removed in the temperature range 95−150 °C, while the bonded MeCN groups of 5 and 6 were removed in the temperature ranges of 128−164 °C and 132−162 °C, respectively, probably indicating that the Ag−N bond is stronger than the Ag−O bond in these complexes. For complexes 9−12 containing nitrate anions, the structure decomposed in the range 190−270 °C for the dinuclear complex 9 and 205−270 °C and 210−265 °C for the 1-D ladderlike chain complexes 10 and 11, respectively, while that for the 2-D complex 12 is 274−385 °C, consistent with the better stability for the 2-D structure. The TGA results also show that complexes 1−13, which contain the ligands with multiphenyl and quinoxalinyl group, are thermally stable and the L ligands decomposed at temperatures above 190 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Properties

The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1-3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, and the first weight loss which is due to the removal one of the L ligands occurred in the similar temperature ranges of 213-266 °C for 1, 218-270 °C for 2 and 214-271 °C for 3, respectively, indicating that the anions ClO4 -, PF6 - and SbF6 - play similar structural role in complexes 1-3. For complexes 4-6 which show 1-D polymeric infinite chains, the cocrystallized and the bonded H2O molecules of 4 were removed in the temperature range 95-150 °C, while the bonded MeCN groups of 5 and 6 were removed in the temperature ranges of 128-164 °C and 132-162 °C, respectively, probably indicating that the Ag-N bond is stronger than the Ag-O bond in these complexes. For complexes 9-12 containing nitrate anions, the structure decomposed in the range 190-270 °C for the dinuclear complex 9 and 205-270 °C and 210-265 °C for the 1-D ladderlike chain complexes 10 and 11, respectively, while that for the 2-D complex 12 is 274-385 °C, consistent with the better stability for the 2-D structure. The TGA results also show that complexes 1-13, which contain the ligands with multiphenyl and quinoxalinyl group, are thermally stable and the L ligands decomposed at temperatures above 190 °C.

elements.content: The luminescent spectra of complexes 1−13, as well as free ligand L, were measured in the solid at room temperature, Figure , and their emission data are listed in Table S4 in the . The emission bands in complexes 1−13 can be tentatively assigned as intraligand (IL) π → π* transition since no significant change was observed upon coordination the L ligands to the metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The luminescent spectra of complexes 1-13, as well as free ligand L, were measured in the solid at room temperature, Figure , and their emission data are listed in Table S4 in the . The emission bands in complexes 1-13 can be tentatively assigned as intraligand (IL) π → π* transition since no significant change was observed upon coordination the L ligands to the metal centers.

elements.content: In the present investigation, we have shown that the reactions of the various Ag(I) salts with L ligands in different solvent systems afforded 0-D monomer and dimer, 1-D chains and 2-D nets. For the complexes with noncoordinating anions, the 0-D mononuclear complexes were prepared in a metal-to-ligand ratio of 1: 2 and that for the 1-D polymeric complexes was 1:1. Both the monomeric complex [Ag(L)2](ClO4), 1, and the polymeric one {[Ag(L)(L′)][ClO4]}∞, 6, containing the small, noncoordinating anion ClO4 − were prepared in CH3OH and CH3CN, respectively, at room temperature. In contrast, both the monomeric complex [Ag(L)2](SbF6), 3, and the polymeric one {[Ag(L)][SbF6]·0.5·CH2Cl2}∞, 8·0.5·CH2Cl2, containing the large, noncoordinating anion SbF6 − were prepared in CH3OH and CH2Cl2, respectively. We have also obtained the polymeric complex [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)·0.5CH3OH·H2O]∞, 7·0.5CH3OH·H2O, containing the large, noncoordinating anion CF3SO3 −. In complexes 1−8, those with coordinated or packed solvent molecules show the polymeric structures, whereas those without solvent molecule are mononuclear. For complexes with noncoordinating anions, the size of the discrete anions is thus not the sole factor that determines the structural type. The metal-to-ligand molar ratio and the nature of the solvents involved in the reactions should be consulted. In complexes 9−12, various types of bonding modes for the coordinating NO3 − anions and different structural types were observed, presumably due to the different coordinating abilities of water, MeCN and DMF. The nature of the solvent thus plays an important role in determining the structural type of Ag(I)−L complex containing coordinating or noncoordinating anion.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In the present investigation, we have shown that the reactions of the various Ag(I) salts with L ligands in different solvent systems afforded 0-D monomer and dimer, 1-D chains and 2-D nets. For the complexes with noncoordinating anions, the 0-D mononuclear complexes were prepared in a metal-to-ligand ratio of 1: 2 and that for the 1-D polymeric complexes was 1:1. Both the monomeric complex [Ag(L)2](ClO4), 1, and the polymeric one {[Ag(L)(L')][ClO4]}∞, 6, containing the small, noncoordinating anion ClO4 - were prepared in CH3OH and CH3CN, respectively, at room temperature. In contrast, both the monomeric complex [Ag(L)2](SbF6), 3, and the polymeric one {[Ag(L)][SbF6]⋅0.5⋅CH2Cl2}∞, 8⋅0.5⋅CH2Cl2, containing the large, noncoordinating anion SbF6 - were prepared in CH3OH and CH2Cl2, respectively. We have also obtained the polymeric complex [Ag(L)(CF3SO3)⋅0.5CH3OH⋅H2O]∞, 7⋅0.5CH3OH⋅H2O, containing the large, noncoordinating anion CF3SO3 -. In complexes 1-8, those with coordinated or packed solvent molecules show the polymeric structures, whereas those without solvent molecule are mononuclear. For complexes with noncoordinating anions, the size of the discrete anions is thus not the sole factor that determines the structural type. The metal-to-ligand molar ratio and the nature of the solvents involved in the reactions should be consulted. In complexes 9-12, various types of bonding modes for the coordinating NO3 - anions and different structural types were observed, presumably due to the different coordinating abilities of water, MeCN and DMF. The nature of the solvent thus plays an important role in determining the structural type of Ag(I)-L complex containing coordinating or noncoordinating anion.

Preparation. (a) [Ag(L)2][ClO4], 1

 L (0.57 g, 2.0 mmol) was placed in a flask containing 15 mL of MeOH, and AgClO4 (0.21 g, 1.0 mmol) was added. The mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 24 h to afford a yellow solution with some white solid. cln_elements.content:
Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1−13. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1−3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, respectively. The first weight loss of 37.0, 35.0 and 30.6% occurred in the temperature range 213−266 °C for 1, 218−270 °C for 2 and 214−271 °C for 3, respectively, presumably due to the removal one of the L ligands per formula unit (calcd 36.6, 34.6 and 31.1%). Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 266−370 °C for 1, 270−314 °C for 2 and 271−382 °C for 3, corresponding to the removal of the second L ligands and decomposition of the structures.

The TGA curve shows that 4 is stable up to 95 °C. A total weight loss of 7.2% occurred in the temperature range 95−150 °C, mainly corresponding to the removal of the cocrystallized and the bonded H2O molecules per formula unit (calcd 7.0%). Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 240−350 °C, consistent with the removal of L ligands and decomposition of the chain structures. TGA curves for 5 and 6 show the loss of the bonded MeCN groups in the range 128−164 °C for 5 and 132−162 °C for 6 (calcd 8.0%, obs 7.7% for 5 and calcd 7.7%, obs 7.4% for 6), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the chains in 260−355 °C for 5 and 250−360 °C for 6, respectively. The TGA curves show that the 1-D chains 7 and 8 are stable up to 210 and 213 °C, respectively. The weight losses occurred in the temperature range 210−434 °C for 7 and 213−440 °C for 8 are due to the removal the L ligands and decomposition of the chain structures.

The TGA curve for 9 shows the loss of the bonded DMF groups in the range 120−160 °C (calcd 19.0%, obs 18.7%), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the structures above 190−270 °C, while those for 10 and 11 show the loss of the bonded H2O or MeCN groups in the range 95−115 °C for 10 and 85−110 °C for 11 (calcd 5.4%, obs 5.7% for 10 and calcd 12.5%, obs 12.4% for 11), followed by the loss of the L ligands and decomposition of the chains above 205−270 °C for 10 and 210−265 °C for 11, respectively. The TGA curves show that the 2-D networks 12 and 13 are stable up to 195 and 200 °C, respectively. The first weight loss of 44.9 and 49.8% occurred in the temperature range 195−274 °C for 12 and 200−344 °C for 13, presumably due to the removal the L ligands per formula unit (calcd 45.4 and 50.3%), respectively. Another weight loss occurred in the temperature range 274−385 °C for 12 and 344−493 °C for 13, corresponding to the removal of the anions and decomposition of the structures.

Thermal Properties

The TGA curves show that the mononuclear complexes 1−3 are stable up to 213, 218, and 214 °C, and the first weight loss which is due to the removal one of the L ligands occurred in the similar temperature ranges of 213−266 °C for 1, 218−270 °C for 2 and 214−271 °C for 3, respectively, indicating that the anions ClO4 −, PF6 − and SbF6 − play similar structural role in complexes 1−3. For complexes 4−6 which show 1-D polymeric infinite chains, the cocrystallized and the bonded H2O molecules of 4 were removed in the temperature range 95−150 °C, while the bonded MeCN groups of 5 and 6 were removed in the temperature ranges of 128−164 °C and 132−162 °C, respectively, probably indicating that the Ag−N bond is stronger than the Ag−O bond in these complexes. For complexes 9−12 containing nitrate anions, the structure decomposed in the range 190−270 °C for the dinuclear complex 9 and 205−270 °C and 210−265 °C for the 1-D ladderlike chain complexes 10 and 11, respectively, while that for the 2-D complex 12 is 274−385 °C, consistent with the better stability for the 2-D structure. The TGA results also show that complexes 1−13, which contain the ligands with multiphenyl and quinoxalinyl group, are thermally stable and the L ligands decomposed at temperatures above 190 °C.
